section: TERM OF CONTRACT The Term of this Agreement shall be for a period of [* ****] years and [*****] months commencing the 1st day of September 2004 and terminating the [*****] day of [*****].
explanation: The discrepancy lies in the ambiguity surrounding the end date of the contract. The contract specifies a start date and a duration in years and months, but the termination date is left unspecified with redactions. This omission creates an in-text contradiction because it's impossible to determine the agreement's length or the obligations' timeline. The contract's term is undefined.

section: MANDATORY PRODUCTS" shall mean the following ADAMS GOLF PRODUCTS that CONSULTANT must exclusively play/use in all Champions/Senior Professional Golf Association (SPGA) and Professional Golf Association (PGA) events at all times: [***** ] Confidential Material redacted and filed separately with the Commission. 2 1.[*****] 2.Sufficient [*****] to maintain total minimum of [*****] ADAMS GOLF [*****] (includes [*****])[*****] at all times 3.[*****] 4.[*****] (CONSULTANT may continue to place the [*****] logo on the [*****] consistent with historical practice.)
explanation: The definition of "MANDATORY PRODUCTS" is significantly redacted, rendering it impossible to understand exactly which ADAMS GOLF products the CONSULTANT is obligated to use exclusively. The redacted material removes key specifics. It creates a contradiction because the agreement emphasizes the exclusive use of MANDATORY PRODUCTS, but fails to clearly define them.

section: During the term of this Agreement, CONSULTANT shall exclusively play/use the MANDATORY PRODUCT, except that CONSULTANT is permitted to use equipment from any manufacturer without restriction, provided he makes a good faith effort to use ADAMS GOLF products whenever possible.
explanation: This section contains an in-text contradiction. It starts by stating that the CONSULTANT shall exclusively use the MANDATORY PRODUCT, but then immediately qualifies this by allowing the CONSULTANT to use equipment from any manufacturer. The requirement to make a "good faith effort" to use ADAMS GOLF products is vague and unenforceable, negating the exclusivity clause and creating conflicting obligations.
